Linguistic analysis: The expert may have analyzed the language used in the claim to determine if it matches the style and vocabulary typically used in authentic news reports. This could include examining grammar, syntax, and word choice.
Source credibility: The expert may have investigated the source of the claim to assess its credibility. This could involve checking if the source is a reputable news organization or if it has a history of spreading false information.
Comparison with existing data: The expert may have compared the claim with existing data on hurricanes to verify its accuracy. They could have looked at historical hurricane patterns, current weather reports, or official hurricane tracking data to see if there is any evidence supporting the claim.
Cross: referencing with other experts: The expert may have consulted with other experts in the field of meteorology or hurricane tracking to get their opinion on the claim. By seeking multiple expert opinions, they can ensure a more comprehensive assessment of the claim's authenticity.
